CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , when the judicial order to pay had become final by virtue of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , PERSON applied to ORG for attachment of a sum of GRD CARDINAL,CARDINAL,CARDINAL in the ORG ’s account at the bank ; the bank , however , did not react .

In the meantime , pursuant to the order to pay obtained ex parte , the ORG issued CARDINAL new payment warrants ( nos . CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) for a total of GRD CARDINAL,CARDINAL,CARDINAL . On DATE , however , the auditor in charge of the file at ORG refused to authorise payment on the ground that ORG was not bound by the fact that the judicial order to pay had become final after expiry of the time allowed for any application to have it set aside . Under ORG settled case - law ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , the effect of orders of this kind is indeed limited and does not correspond to that referred to in LAW para . CARDINAL of Presidential Decree no . CARDINAL on ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . An ex parte order to pay therefore does not constitute a judicial act comparable to a final court decision .
CARDINAL . ORG The relevant provisions of LAW are as follows :

" Under the special procedure set out in Articles CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure , an order to pay may be sought in respect of a pecuniary claim or CARDINAL pertaining to securities if the debt and the amount owed are proved by an officially recorded document or a private one . "

" The justice of the peace shall be competent to issue an order to pay where the claim comes within the jurisdiction of his court . In all other cases a single judge of the court of first instance shall be competent . No hearing shall be held upon an application for an order to pay . "
" The judge shall rule on the application as soon as possible , without summoning the debtor to attend ... ; the judge shall , however , be entitled
( a ) to require the applicant to attend to give explanations answering his application ;
" CARDINAL . The judge shall dismiss the application
( a ) if the legal requirements for making an order to pay are not satisfied ;
" The judge shall grant the application in so far as it is , in his view , founded in law and in fact , and shall order the debtor to pay the sum due and legal costs ... "
" A judicial order to pay shall be enforceable . "

" A debtor against whom an order to pay has been issued may apply to have it set aside within DATE of service of the order . The application to set aside shall be made to the court having jurisdiction ratione materiae to hear the case . "

" CARDINAL . If an application to set aside has been properly made within the time prescribed by law and the reasons given for it are lawful and well - founded , the court shall set aside the order to pay ; otherwise it shall dismiss the application to set aside and confirm the order to pay .

CARDINAL . If the application to set aside has not been made within the time prescribed by law , the party in favour of whom the order to pay has been made may again serve that order on the debtor , who shall again be entitled to apply to have it set aside within DATE ... If no application to set aside has been made within that time , the order to pay shall become final and may only be challenged by means of proceedings to reopen the case . "
CARDINAL . ORG In a decision adopted at the tenth session of the full court on DATE ORG held :

" It follows from the [ aforementioned ] provisions ... that when verifying the lawfulness of expenditure , ORG also , if necessary , verifies the entitlement of the creditor of the ORG , local authority or other public - law entity . If the issue of entitlement has become res judicata ( within the meaning of Articles CARDINAL et seq . of ORG ) as a result of a judgment by a civil court , that judgment is binding on ORG .
It is clear that the estoppel per rem judicatam which thus prevents ORG reopening that issue derives from the fact that the civil court has examined the merits , in law and in fact , of the claim ...

If , further , it is taken into consideration that by LAW para . CARDINAL ( b ) of LAW , an order to pay does not create an estoppel per rem judicatam but merely ‘ becomes final’ , it may be asserted that the effect of an ex parte order to pay , just like its limits in objective and subjective terms , is not identical with that of a court decision and of its functions and limits .

This is because an order to pay is not a court decision and , by Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( b ) of LAW , is made , after the special procedure laid down in Articles CARDINAL et seq . of that Code , solely to provide an enforceable instrument .

The review undertaken when an application is made under ORG CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure to set aside an order to pay does not cover the right in issue but relates merely to the validity of the order to pay as an enforceable instrument .

In the light of the foregoing , accepting the contrary argument that the effect of an order to pay does not differ from that of a court decision or is not of limited scope is to call in question the constitutionality of the effect of an order to pay , as the latter is made without the debtor being summoned and without any adversarial hearing

It must therefore be considered that the effect of an order to pay is merely to deprive the defendant of his right to raise preliminary objections unreasonably , such an estoppel resembling ... the negative aspect of the estoppel per rem judicatam created by a court decision ( in that the objections may not be considered again ) .

Consequently , the effect of an order to pay does not extend to a finding as to the right in issue ( the positive aspect of res judicata ) ; that being so , ORG is not bound by such an order when it verifies the lawfulness of expenditure , the claim merely being made enforceable by such an order .

None of the foregoing deprives an order to pay of its enforceability , although naturally that does not prejudice the provisions on immunity from execution enjoyed under LAW no . ORG by ORG and , as a result of a broad construction of that statute , by local authorities and other public - law entities .

Acknowledgment and settlement of expenditure , like the orders to pay relating to it , presuppose that the right of the creditor of the ORG , local authority or other public - law entity has been proved by means of relevant documents , as it is not sufficient to rely on a claim whose enforceability derives from a judicial order to pay , even if that order has become final .

It must accordingly be accepted that when verifying the lawfulness of expenditure , ORG is not bound by the limited effect of the order to pay ... , as that effect does not have the characteristics of the binding force referred to in paragraph CARDINAL of LAW no . DATE on ORG .

It follows that the right conferred by the effect of the order to pay on the person who is claiming to be entitled to the amount of the expenditure does not ipso facto make that expenditure lawful and that ORG is under an obligation to verify the lawfulness of that expenditure in all its aspects . "
